<<<explanation>>>: Why are you reading each byte individually? It looks like you really want to read the first 3 bytes and figure out your length and then read that block. Then you can at least get the optimizations that Inputstream can provide for reading blocks of data rather than one byte at a time. And you are not allocating that mega array like you currently have.
Question: How can I create constrained InputStream to read only part of the file?: :I want to create an InputStream that is limited to a certain range of bytes in file, e.g. to bytes from position 0 to 100. So that the client code should see EOF once 100th byte is reached.
Please using this api: InputStream.read.
Answer:<<<api>>>: InputStream.read
<<<code>>>: 
```java
public class PartialInputStream extends InputStream {
    private final InputStream in;
    private long pos, limit;

    public PartialInputStream(InputStream in, long limit) {
        this.in = in;
        this.limit = limit;
    }

    @Override
    public int read() throws IOException {
        if (pos++ >= limit) {
            return -1;
        } else {
            return in.read();
        }
    }
}
```
<<<explanation>>>: You can create a new InputStream that wraps your original InputStream and limits it to a certain number of bytes. It does this by overriding the read() method to check the current position and return -1 when the limit is reached.

Please note that this code assumes that the file size does not exceed the maximum value of a long. If the file size can be larger than this, you would need to use a different approach to track the position.

You can use this PartialInputStream like this:
```java
try (InputStream is = new PartialInputStream(client.getInputStream(), 100)) {
    // read from is
}
```
This will create a new InputStream that reads from the original InputStream, but stops after reading 100 bytes.

Also, remember to close the InputStream when you're done with it to free up system resources.
